plain_roti.title: Plain Roti (Flatbread)
plain_roti.recipe:
1.  Combine 200g atta flour, 2.0g sea salt, and 170g room temperature water.
2. Knead for 6-8 minutes until smooth and pliable. Rest for 10-15 minutes. 
3.  Divide the dough into 6 equal pieces (pedas). Roll each into a 6-7 inch thin circle, lightly dusting with flour. 
4. Cook: Heat a tawa (griddle) over medium-high heat.
5. Cook the roti for 10-15 seconds, flip, cook for 30 seconds to 1 minute, then transfer to a direct flame or press on the tawa to puff and serve hot.

aloo_sabji.title: Dry Aloo Sabzi (Potato Curry)
aloo_sabji.recipe:
1. Boil 2-3 medium potatoes until tender but firm. Peel and cut them into bite-sized pieces.
 2. Finely chop 3/4 cup red onions and 2 garlic cloves. Coarsely grind 1/2 tablespoon of dry roasted coriander seeds. 
3. Heat 1.5 tablespoons of cooking oil in a pan over medium heat. Add 1/2 teaspoon of cumin seeds. Once they sizzle, add the chopped onions and garlic. Fry until the onions are just turning reddish brown.
4. Add the pre-cut potatoes and all the ground/powder spices (1/4 tsp red chili powder, 1/4 tsp turmeric powder, 1/4 tsp black salt, 1/4 tsp mango powder). 
5.Stir well to coat the potatoes with the spices and cook for 4-5 minutes without adding water. 
6. Finish: Stir in 1/2 cup chopped cilantro leaves. Top with 1 slit green chili (optional) and 1/2 tablespoon lemon juice (optional).
7. Serve hot with the Roti.

samosa.recipe:
Samosa Dough
1. In a bowl, combine 3/4 cup (90g) all-purpose flour, 1/4 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon ajwain.
 2. Add Fat: Rub in 1.5 tablespoons of ghee or oil with your fingertips until the mixture resembles coarse breadcrumbs (this is the 'moyen' that creates a flaky crust). 
3. Gradually add 3-4 tablespoons of cold water and knead the mixture into a tight, stiff dough. Do not over-knead. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.

  Potato Filling
1. Boil 2 medium potatoes until tender. Peel and coarsely mash them. 
2. Heat 1 teaspoon of oil in a small pan. Add 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add 1/2 teaspoon ginger-garlic paste (optional) and 1/4 cup chopped onion (optional). Saute until the onion is translucent.
 3. Turn off the heat. Stir in the chopped green chili, 1/2 teaspoon coriander powder, 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder, 1/4 teaspoon red chili powder, 1/4 teaspoon amchur (mango powder), and salt to taste. 
4. Combine: Add the mashed potatoes and 1 tablespoon chopped green peas (optional) to the pan. Mix everything well. 
5. Stir in 1 tablespoon fresh coriander leaves. Cool the filling completely.

  Assemble and Fry
1. Divide the dough into 2-3 equal balls. Roll each ball into a thin oval shape. 
2. Cut the oval in half (down the middle). Take one half, moisten the straight edge with water, and fold it into a cone shape, pinching the seam tightly.
 3. Fill and Seal: Spoon 1.5-2 tablespoons of the potato filling into the cone. Moisten the open edges with water and pinch the top seam tightly to seal the samosa, creating a stable, triangular shape. 
4. Heat oil in a deep kadai over low-medium heat. The oil should be warm, not smoking hot (this is crucial for a crisp, flaky crust).
5. Gently add the samosas and fry slowly, turning occasionally, for about 10-15 minutes until they are golden brown and crisp. 
6. Serve: Drain excess oil and serve hot with tamarind chutney and mint/coriander chutney.

chicken.recipe:
1. Cut Meat: Cut 300g boneless chicken into 1-inch pieces.
 2. Marinate: Combine the chicken with all marinade ingredients (ginger-garlic paste, oil, lemon juice, chili powder, cumin, coriander, salt, Sekuwa Masala).
 3. Mix well and marinate for a minimum of 4 hours, or preferably overnight in the refrigerator. 
 4. Skewer: Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto metal or soaked wooden skewers. 
 5. Grill: Grill the skewers over hot coals (or bake at 200°C/400°F, turning occasionally) for 10-15 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and slightly charred. 
  Serve hot with puffed rice (chiura) and Sekuwa chutney.

mutton.recipe:
1. Cut Meat: Cut 300g mutton  into 1-inch pieces. 
 2. Marinate: Combine mutton with all marinade ingredients (mustard oil is highly recommended for mutton), ensuring it's mixed thoroughly.
 3. Marinate for a minimum of 6 hours, or overnight for best results. Mutton requires longer marination than chicken. 
 4. Skewer & Grill: Thread and grill over hot coals for 15-20 minutes, turning frequently, until tender and cooked through. 
 5. Serve hot with Sekuwa chutney and puffed rice.

buff.recipe:
1. Cut Meat: Cut 300g buff meat (leaner cuts) into 1-inch pieces. 
 2. Marinate: Marinate the buff with all spices, oil, and lemon juice. Marinate for the longest time (8-12 hours) to help tenderize the meat. 
 3. Adding a tablespoon of grated raw papaya can also help tenderize. 
 4. Skewer & Grill: Thread and grill for 15-20 minutes, or until desired doneness, ensuring the pieces are cooked thoroughly. Buff typically takes slightly longer than mutton. 
 5. Enjoy hot with Sekuwa chutney.

pork.recipe:
1. Cut Meat: Cut 300g pork (shoulder/belly with some fat is ideal) into 1-inch pieces. 
 2. Marinate: Combine the pork with all marinade ingredients.The Sekuwa Masala complements the pork flavor well.
 3 Marinate for 4-6 hours. 
 4. Skewer & Grill: Thread and grill for 15-20 minutes, or until the pork fat is nicely rendered and the meat is thoroughly cooked. 
 5. Serve immediately as the fat tends to harden quickly once cold.

Selroti.recipe:
1.  Take 1/2 cup of rice (long-grain or short-grain) and wash it. Pour enough water to submerge the rice and let it soak overnight. 
 2. Drain the soaked rice. In a mixer or blender, combine the rice with 1 tablespoon ghee, 2 tablespoons sugar, 1/2 teaspoon cardamom powder, and 3-4 tablespoons of water (start with less, adding only enough to help the blender move).
 3. Blend until you get a smooth, creamy batter. The batter consistency should be just pourable but not watery. 
 4.  Transfer the batter to a bowl and let it rest for about 15 minutes. 
 5. Prepare Frying: Pour enough oil into a kadhai (deep frying pan) for deep frying and heat it over medium flame. The oil should be hot, but not smoking. 
 6. Shape and Fry: Pour the batter into a piping bag (or use your hand, letting the batter fall from the bottom of a fisted hand). Starting from the center, let the batter fall into the hot oil, moving in a continuous circle to form a doughnut shape. 
 7. Cook: Once the Sel Roti rises to the surface, turn it over using a long stick or tongs. Cook until both sides are a uniform golden-brown color (about 1-2 minutes per side). 
 8. Serve: Transfer the Sel Roti to a plate lined with paper towels to drain excess oil. Continue frying the rest of the batter, adjusting the flame as necessary to maintain a consistent oil temperature.
 9. Serve warm.

ingredients.name: rice (preferably raw, long or short grain)

Sohan_Papdi.recipe:
Prepare Roasted Flour
1.  1/4 cup (approx 30g) gram flour (Besan) and 1/4 cup (approx 30g) maida (All-Purpose Flour) together.
  2. Heat 50ml (approx 3.5 Tbsp) Ghee in a heavy pan. 
 3. Add the sifted flour mixture and roast over low-medium heat, stirring continuously, until the flour turns light golden and is aromatic. Remove from heat and set aside.

  Prepare Sugar Syrup
1. Combine: In a separate pan, combine 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 cup water, and 1 tablespoon milk (for purification).
 2. Place over low-medium heat and stir until the sugar dissolves. 
 3. Simmer the syrup. As it heats, use a spoon to skim off any impurities that float to the top. 
 4. Continue simmering without stirring until the syrup reaches a two-thread consistency (when dropped between your thumb and forefinger, it forms two thin threads before breaking). This is a crucial step.
 5. Immediately remove from heat.

  Flaking
1. Pour the hot sugar syrup into the roasted flour mixture. Mix quickly and thoroughly until combined. 
 2. Pull and Flake : Pour the mixture onto a greased surface. As it cools slightly, fold and pull the mixture apart repeatedly (this is the technique that creates the flaky threads). Continue folding, pulling, and mixing until the mixture breaks down into fine, thread-like flakes (the 'papdi').
  3. Set: Transfer the flaky mixture into a small greased plate or tray and gently pat it flat to a thickness of about 1 inch. Do not press hard.
  4. Sprinkle with crushed cardamoms and chopped almonds and pistachios. Gently press them into the surface.
  5.  Allow to cool slightly (while still warm), then cut into small squares. Let it cool completely before covering with polythene squares (optional) and storing in an airtight container.

chicken_fry.recipe:
1. Soak the dried chicken sukuti in warm water for 15-20 minutes to soften slightly.
 2. Drain and squeeze out excess water. 
 3.  Heat 1 tablespoon of oil in a pan.
 4. Fry the sukuti until it is crisp and darkens slightly. Remove and set aside. 
 5.  In the same pan, add 1/2 tablespoon oil.
 6. Add 1/2 tsp cumin seeds and 1/4 tsp fenugreek seeds (methi). 
 6. Once they splutter, add the ginger-garlic paste and sliced onion. Saute until the onion is soft. 
 7. Spice and Finish: Stir in turmeric, chili powder, and salt. 
 8. Return the fried sukuti to the pan and toss well to coat with spices.
 9. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
 10. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot.

mutton_fry.recipe:
1. Soak dried mutton sukuti in warm water for 20-30 minutes.
 2. Drain and pan-fry in 1 tablespoon of oil until crisp. Set aside. 
 3. In the same pan, heat 1/2 tablespoon oil. 
 4. Add 1/2 tsp cumin seeds and 1/4 tsp fenugreek seeds. 
 5.Add ginger-garlic paste and sliced onion.
 6. Saute until onion is soft. 
 7. Add turmeric, chili powder, and salt. 
 8. Return the fried sukuti to the pan and toss well. 
 9. For extra flavor, add 1/2 tsp Sukuti/Garam Masala. 
 10. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
 11. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot.

sukuti_sadheko.recipe:
1. Prepare Sukuti: Rehydrate dried sukuti (chicken or mutton) by either soaking for 30 minutes, or lightly frying until crisp.
 2. Cut into smaller pieces if necessary. 
 3. Combine: In a bowl, combine the prepared sukuti with chopped ginger, sliced onion, chopped tomato, and coriander leaves. 
 4. Add Spices: Add Sekuwa/Garam Masala, chili powder, and salt. 
 5. Temper/Dress: Heat mustard oil until smoking hot (this is essential for flavor). Turn off the heat.
 6. Add fenugreek seeds and let them turn dark brown.
 7. Immediately pour the hot oil (with the fenugreek) over the sukuti mixture.  Mix well.
 8. Add lemon juice for tanginess.
 9. Serve immediately as a cold/room-temperature appetizer.

Thakuwa.recipe:
1. Prepare Jaggery/Sugar Water: In a small saucepan, combine 1/4 cup sugar (or grated jaggery) with 1/4 cup water. 
2 Heat gently until the sugar/jaggery completely dissolves.
3. Do not boil into a syrup. Let it cool completely. 
4. In a mixing bowl, take 1/2 cup (60g) whole wheat flour (atta) and 1 teaspoon rava (semolina). Add 1/2 tsp fennel seeds (saunf) and 1/4 tsp cardamom powder. Mix well. 
5. Add 1.5 tablespoons melted ghee. Rub the ghee into the flour mixture with your fingertips until it resembles coarse breadcrumbs and holds its shape when pressed lightly (this ensures crispness). 
6.  Gradually pour the cooled sugar/jaggery water into the flour mixture. Mix and knead lightly to form a stiff and tight dough. Do not over-knead or it will lose its crisp texture. Add a few drops of plain water only if necessary.
7. Cover and let it rest for 10-15 minutes. 
8. Divide the dough into 4-5 equal balls. Flatten each ball with your palm. Use a traditional Thakuwa mold to press a pattern on the disc, or simply use the tines of a fork or the back of a skewer to create a decorative pattern. 
9.  Heat oil or ghee for deep frying over low-medium flame. This is crucial—Thakuwa must be fried slowly.
10. Gently drop the shaped discs into the warm oil. 
11. Fry for 8-10 minutes, turning gently, until they are deep golden brown and crisp on both sides.
12. Drain them onto a paper towel. The Thakuwa will be soft when hot, but will turn hard and crunchy once completely cool. 
13.  Store in an airtight container once cooled. Serve as a sweet snack.

Til_ko_Laddu.display_name: Til ko Laddu (Sesame Seed Jaggery Balls)

white_til.recipe:
1. Roast Sesame: Dry roast 1/2 cup white sesame seeds in a pan over low-medium heat, stirring constantly until they are lightly golden and fragrant (about 5-7 minutes).
2. Be careful not to burn them. Let them cool.
 3. In the same pan, heat 3/4 cup crushed jaggery (gud) with 1 tablespoon water/ghee on low heat. 
4.Stir continuously until the jaggery melts completely and thickens into a syrup.
5. The syrup should reach a soft ball stage when tested in cold water—it should form a soft, chewable ball. 
6. Immediately turn off the heat. Stir in the roasted white sesame seeds and 1/4 tsp cardamom powder (optional). Mix quickly and thoroughly. 
7. Shape: Lightly grease your palms with ghee or water.
8. While the mixture is still hot (but manageable), take small portions and roll them quickly into smooth, round laddus (balls). 
9. Allow the laddus to cool and harden completely before serving or storing.

3. For an easier bind, you can lightly pulse the cooled black sesame seeds in a grinder for a few seconds (do not make a paste).

6. Turn off the heat. Stir in the roasted black sesame seeds and 1/4 tsp ginger powder (optional, common in this variation). Mix quickly and thoroughly. 
7. Lightly grease your palms with ghee or water. While the mixture is still hot, quickly roll them into smooth, round laddus. 
8.  Let the laddus cool and set before serving.

Yomari.recipe:
Preparing Dough
1. In a bowl, combine 2/3 cup (100g) rice flour and 3 tablespoons (25g) all-purpose flour and mix well.
 2.  Gradually add 1/4 cup warm water and knead well to form a soft dough.
3. Ensure the dough is smooth and pliable.
4. Cover and set aside to rest for 10 minutes.

  Preparing Jaggery Filling
1.  Heat a saucepan over medium heat.
2. Add 2/3 cup (100g) crushed jaggery. Keep stirring continuously until the jaggery melts completely into a thick syrup. 
3. Add 2 tablespoons milk and stir for a minute to combine and slightly clean the syrup. 
4.  Check the consistency by taking a pinch between your fingers—it should be thick and slightly sticky. 
5.  Remove from heat. 
6. Pour the jaggery syrup into a bowl and stir in 1 teaspoon sesame seeds (fried/toasted is best) and 1/2 tablespoon ghee/oil for a richer flavor. Let the filling cool slightly.

  Making and Steaming Yomari
1. Shape: Lightly oil your hands. Take a small, egg-sized ball of dough.
2. Roll it round, then gently shape it into a cone. 
3.  Dip your forefinger in warm water mixed with a little ghee/oil and gradually press down to create a smooth, deep cavity inside the cone without creating a hole at the bottom. 
4. Fill the cavity halfway with the cooled jaggery and sesame seed mixture.
5. Hold the base of the cone and gently pinch and press the upper part of the cone using your forefinger and thumb to seal the mouth and give it the final Yomari shape. 
6. Arrange the Yomari in a steamer (you can place them on a banana leaf or greased plate).
7. Steam for 10-15 minutes, or until the Yomari dough looks shiny and firm. 
8. Serve: Serve warm.
